Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of song culture in zebra finches - vocal and sensory changes over generations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Culture consists of traits transmitted through social learning. One example for social learning is the acquisition of song by songbirds: During a sensitive period early in life, young males learn to imitate their father's song. Songbirds provide tractable models of culture: Members of a species show individual variation in song, and geographically separated groups have local song dialects, i.e., a local song culture. How does song culture develop over multiple generations? In zebra finches, birds kept isolated during the sensitive period develop an abnormal (isolate) song. Interestingly, in an isolated colony founded by an isolate, "normal" songs with species-typical features emerge within 3-4 generations, due to biased imitation that gradually transforms the isolate song into the species-typical song. Understanding how song develops in individual birds and how song culture develops in a community might require knowledge not only about the vocal, but also about the sensory-perceptual development across generations, as well as the social interactions which accompany it. This project is a combined study of social, vocal, and sensory aspects of song development. The investigators will design controlled social environments to examine dynamically how song is acquired and how song culture emerges. They will combine the continuous analysis of vocal changes and social interactions with non-invasive functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) of the brain to investigate how auditory brain responses to songs develop, and how they drive cultural changes. Moreover, these researchers will test if developmental changes in brain architecture correlate with observed vocal and/or sensory changes using diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).

This research will provide a bridge between studies of vocal and sensory changes and ethology studies of cultural changes in vocal communication. This project will contribute to the training of three graduate students, and provide scientific education and research training to undergraduate students as well as middle and high school students in the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learned birdsong is a useful model system for studying developmental vocal and social learning. In particular, studies on the brain mechanisms of vocal learning in songbirds can offer insights into the development of speech and language, as well as into speech motor control disorders such as autism developmental stuttering. The completed project in a joint effort between my Laboratory of Vocal Learning at Hunter College, The Henning Voss laboratory at the imaging center of Weill Medical College of Cornell University, and the Santosh Helekar laboratory at the Institute of Academic Medicine of Houston Methodist Hospital. The project aimed at studying how social interactions affected song learning in zebra finches, who imitate their adult tutors during development, and to study how the development of the ability of the brain to perceive vocal sounds impacts the development of songs produced by these birds.

My laboratory developed behavioral methods, including vocal robots that can train birds to learn songs in laboratory environment, methods for tracking how birds learn to coordinate their vocalizations, and methods for assessing how birds (male, females, juveniles) respond behaviorally to songs, and measuring songs reinforcement. These methods allowed us to discover how songbirds learn to coordinate their vocalization during development, and to identify brain areas involved in social coordination.

Our behavioral methods also enabled our group to complement behavioral experiments with minimally invasive brain imaging techniques, to detect responses to vocal sounds in different areas of the bird brain. Our laboratory also contributed to the analysis of functional magnetic resonance brain imaging during song stimuli, and to the performance, interpretation and analysis of Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scans for detecting changes in brain dopamine during song stimuli. Studies reveals that in zebra finches, which are highly social and non-territorial songbirds, hearing songs activated the brain dopaminergic reward circuitry in males but not in unmated females. This is surprising because in most birdsong species, song typically attracts females and repels males. Only in mated females that were ready to breed was dopamine response to mate song detectable, and its magnitude correlated with the pair's reproductive success. Therefore, in social songbirds song-triggered dopaminergic activation serves a dual function: providing low-threshold social reinforcement in males, and ultra-selective sexual reinforcement in females. It is likely that the function of this dual function is to promote the evolutionary transition from repelling (territorial) to cohesive social behavior. Co-evolution of high tolerance to song in males, combined with a highly selective reinforcement threshold in females, could enable the coexistence of gregariousness and monogamy.

In terms of contribution to education, our lab trained three undergraduate students, three graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow.

To conclude, the outcomes of this project in terms of methods developed and knowledge gained are of much significance to understanding the neurobiology of vocal learning. Discoveries made by this project, about brain mechanisms of vocal coordination, and about the likely role of brain dopamine in the co-evolution of social aggregation and monogamy, are important in revealed clues about the neurological basis of social behavior, vocal learning, and developmental disorders in vocal and social behaviors.
